description.narrative: Food Security and Sustainable Livelihoods Programme

Drought and other natural disaster affected communities have access to safe and environmentally sustainable water sources for livestock, agricultural and domestic uses to enhance their livelihoods opportunities..
first-order administrative division
first-order administrative division
first-order administrative division
policy, planning and administration

# of months the target households feed themselves from own harvest
# of HHs engaged in bee keeping as an income generating activity

comment.narrative:
• Mean number of months that households are able to feed themselves from their harvest is between 2 & 4 months (Baseline Survey-Emergency Response Addressing Livelihoods, 2010)
• All the targeted households depend on crops and/or livestock for their source of income

Secure access of water in Afentra, Gash Barka region and Unalalai, Maekel regions and support Debub region in soil and water conservation including construction of check dams through community participation. Support will also be given to drought and locust affected Northern and Southern Red Sea regions.

Water sources (micro-dams) have been built in Gash Barka region, Afentra village and Maekel region in Unalali village to supplement the rain fed agriculture of the regions. The micro-dams will be used for livestock drink, small sacle irrigation and domestic use. It is expected that the micro-dams will boost the underground water table, providing potential to sink a downstream well for human consumption. UNDP has also supported seven villages in sub-region of Maimine, Debub region in soil and water conservation activities. Heavily eroded land and gullies created by floods and water run offs were treated with soil and water conservation structures, such as gabion, dry masonry check dams and terraces. The project has increased food supply and security by improving purchasing capacity of target population through cash for work and has met some basic needs of the farmers in response to this year’s crop harvest failure and motivated women and youth to participate in employment generating activities. 10,384 beneficiaries (51% female) of which 84,190 people have received improved seeds for the coming rainy season, and about 1000 small ruminants (3 for each beneficiary) distributed to 333 households (1,665 people) based on the already established criteria by the local authorities. The distribution which includes pregnant dairy goats and improved seeds are expected to alleviate the food problems of the affected population immediately and also sustain the livelihoods of the communities beyond the project life. Without this support, the situation of the affected communities may have been precarious and may turn from bad to worse. The small ruminants are locally adapted breeds to help acquire resistance to diseases and harsh climate.

So far no legal protected area policy and institutional framework to operationalize national protected area systems has been prepared thus no legally designated national protected area has been established as no regulatory framework has been prepared yet. Formulation of this regulatory framework is planned to be initiated in the fourth quarter of 2015 and consultation is under way to facilitate the process.
